newsitem.title: FRANCE: DEHAENE MEETS JOSPIN ON RENAULT CLOSURE.
newsitem.headline: DEHAENE MEETS JOSPIN ON RENAULT CLOSURE.

text.p: Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene met his newly elected French counterpart Lionel Jospin on Saturday to discuss European issues and the closure of the Belgian Renault plant.
"Thank you for seeing me so quickly," Dehaene told Jospin on arriving at the new Socialist prime minister's Paris offices for their talks.

Dehaene said on Thursday he wanted to discuss Renault's decision to close its Vilvoorde plant with Jospin before June 10, when both the carmaker's board of directors and its shareholders have set meetings.
Renault shareholders include the French state.
Renault, which announced the closure with 3,100 job losses in February, reiterated on Wednesday its intention to go ahead with plans to cut costs and streamline its European car assembly operations.
Dehaene, who lives in Vilvoorde, has branded next month's planned closure as "unacceptable."
The Belgian prime minister was likely to remind Jospin of an election promise that he would ask Renault to study alternatives to allow the plant to remain open.
The French Socialist Party, part of Jospin's government, said on Wednesday it also opposed the closure.

Dehaene's Paris trip was part of a campaign to preserve jobs. Louis Tobback, head of the Flemish Socialist Party, has urged Jospin to delay the closure of the assembly plant and start discussions about alternatives. Renault lost 5.25 billion francs ($901.2 million) last year and is struggling to break even this year.

Renault-Vilvoorde workers have said they will halt work ahead of the June 10 meetings. Production at the plant has been patchy since employees voted to end a six-week strike which followed February's news of the closure.
